to initiate debit entries and adjustments for any

This authority is to remain in full force until
has received written notification from me of its
termination in such timely manner as to give
and my financial institution a reasonable
opportunity to act on it,
or until the termination of my employment.

Create a default account
Because your pay could vary from pay period
to pay period, you must create a default account.
A default account is like a safety net
and it ensures that all of your pay is designated
to a bank account.
Your default account is designated at 100%.
That is, 100% of anything that is left over
after all other distributions have been made.
Click 'Continue' to enter your default account information.

Number Of Accounts
Enter the number of accounts you intend to open.
If you plan to open more than one account,
you will be asked to enter information regarding
a default account first.
A default account is one where any extra pay you
receive will be deposited (pay that has not been
designated for a specific institution account).
The system requires that it be designated as 100%
(that is, 100% of anything that is left after
all other deposits have been made).
Deposit All
Select yes or no based on whether you plan to have
all of your pay deposited through Direct Deposit.
If you select yes, you will be asked to enter
information regarding a default account first.
designated for a specific bank account).
Deposits are made into your accounts based on the
order you define, except for a default account.
A default account is always deposited last.
If you do not define a deposit order,
they are deducted in the order in which you
entered them into the system.
To change the deposit order, type a number that
indicates the order in the "Select Order" column.
Create A Default
Deposit All - Yes/No
If you select yes,
you will not be able to specify an amount.
The system will open this as a default account.
As a result, it will be defined as 100%.
The number of direct deposit accounts
you may have active at one time
is stated on the top of the screen.
If you reach the maximum, you must close
an account before opening another one.
If you enroll in direct deposit,
you must deposit all of your net pay.
You cannot deposit a portion of your check
and receive the remainder in a paycheck.
Because this is a default account,
the system automatically defines it as 100%.
Default Account
You may select or enter a bank name.
If you select an institution
the name, institution, and transit numbers
will automatically be entered.
You have the ability to enter
a different transit number, if necessary.
Enter a description of the type of account
to which you are depositing,
i.e., checking, savings, vacation, mortgage, etc.
Institution/Transit/Account Numbers
Sometimes the numbers on checks and deposit slips
differ, so it is important that you determine
your institution, transit and account numbers
by looking at one of your personal checks
(rather than a deposit slip).
If you are opening an account with a credit union
or a savings account, we suggest you confirm
the institution, transit and account numbers
with that institution.
The institution number is a four-digit number that
appears in the bottom left corner of your check.
The transit number is the five-digit number that
appears next to the institution number.
The account number is printed next to
the transit number on the bottom of your check.
Account Number/Institution Name Change
If you change your account number, your new
account is opened with the same institution name,
institution and transit numbers.
To change your institution name,
you must contact your payroll department.
Pre-notification Process
Please note that the first pay period
after enrolling in direct deposit,
you will still receive a payroll check
due to a pre-notification process.
Pre-notification is where a zero deposit amount
transaction is sent through the system
to validate that the routing transit
and bank account numbers are correct.
If you select the bank, the name and
the routing number
a different routing number, if necessary.
Type of Account (Checking - Savings)
Typically, if you can write checks against
an account, it is a checking account.
With a savings account,
you do not write checks against it and, generally,
use deposit or withdrawal slips only.
Routing/Account Numbers
your routing and account numbers
the routing and account numbers with that bank.
The routing number is the nine-digit number that
It is also referred to as an ABA number
or Transit Routing number.
the routing number on the bottom of your check.
Account Number/Bank Name Change
account is opened with the same bank name
and routing number.
To change your bank name,
Default Example (Full Auto Deposit)
For example, you have set up two accounts:
A checking account and a savings account.
You have determined that your checking account
will be your default account.
If your net pay is $1,000, and you deposit $50
into your savings account, the amount deposited
into your checking (default) account is $950.
If for some reason you should receive $100
of additional pay (bonus/commissions/overtime),
your net pay would be $1,100.
Fifty dollars would go to your savings account
and $1,050 would be deposited into
your checking account because the default account
takes 100% of the remaining balance.
Deposit Sequence
Deposits are made into your accounts in the order
in which you enter them into the system,
except for your default account.
Your default account is always deposited last.
However, you have the ability to redefine
the deposit sequence but the default account
will always be deposited last.
Deposit Amount/Percent
If you want to deposit a percent of your net pay
into an account, click Percent and type
the number indicating the percent to be deposited.
You do not need to type the percent sign.
If you want to deposit a flat amount
into an account, click Amount and type the amount
that should be deposited into the account.
You do not need to type the amount sign.
If the deposit amount is a whole number,
you do not need to type the decimal point.
Change Amount
Because this is your default account, you cannot
change the amount that is being deposited.
If you want to change the amount,
you must designate a new default account.
You may deposit all or a portion of your net pay.
A default account ensures that all of your net pay
is allocated somewhere.
If you choose to deposit only a portion
of your net pay, your paycheck will act like
your default account.
However, if you choose to deposit all
of your net pay via direct deposit,
you must specify a default account.
Default Example (Partial Auto Deposit)
You have decided that you want $50 of your pay
deposited into a holiday fund.
The remainder you want to receive
via normal paycheck distribution.
In this situation, your paycheck becomes
the default account.
If for some reason you should receive additional
pay (bonus/commission/overtime), that extra pay
would show up in your paycheck,
not your holiday fund.
You may select the institution name.
you cannot specify an amount.
It must be designated as 100%.
Effective Date
Changes made on this screen may or may not
be reflected on your next paycheck,
depending on your payroll cutoff.
That is, if you update a direct deposit account
the day before payday, it is unlikely
that your change will appear on your paycheck
until the following payroll cycle.
Direct Deposit Account
Authorization
You will be presented with this authorization form
when you add, close or make a change
to a direct deposit account.
With this authorization form you give consent
to your employer to interact with
your institution(s)
your bank(s)
when depositing your pay and, if necessary,
correcting any errors.

Because your pay could vary from pay period to pay period, you must create a default account.
A default account is like a safety net and it ensures that all of your pay is designated to a bank account.
Your default account is designated at 100%. That is, 100% of anything that is left over after all other distributions have been made.
Enter the number of accounts you intend to open. If you plan to open more than one account, you will be asked to enter information regarding a default account first.

A default account is one where any extra pay you receive will be deposited (pay that has not been designated for a specific institution account). The system requires that it be designated as 100% (that is, 100% of anything that is left after all other deposits have been made).
Select yes or no based on whether you plan to have all of your pay deposited through Direct Deposit.
If you select yes, you will be asked to enter information regarding a default account first.

A default account is one where any extra pay you receive will be deposited (pay that has not been designated for a specific bank account). The system requires that it be designated as 100%(that is, 100% of anything that is left after all other deposits have been made).

Deposits are made into your accounts based on the order you define, except for a default account. A default account is always deposited last. If you do not define a deposit order, they are deducted in the order in which you entered them into the system.
To change the deposit order, type a number that indicates the order in the "Select Order" column.
If you select yes, you will not be able to specify an amount. The system will open this as a default account. As a result, it will be defined as 100%.
The number of direct deposit accounts you may have active at one time is stated on the top of the screen. If you reach the maximum, you must close an account before opening another one.
If you enroll in direct deposit, you must deposit all of your net pay. You cannot deposit a portion of your check and receive the remainder in a paycheck.
Because this is a default account, the system automatically defines it as 100%.

You may select or enter a bank name. If you select an institution the name, institution, and transit numbers will automatically be entered. You have the ability to enter a different transit number, if necessary.
Enter a description of the type of account to which you are depositing, i.e., checking, savings, vacation, mortgage, etc.

Sometimes the numbers on checks and deposit slips differ, so it is important that you determine your institution, transit and account numbers by looking at one of your personal checks (rather than a deposit slip). If you are opening an account with a credit union or a savings account, we suggest you confirm the institution, transit and account numbers with that institution.

The institution number is a four-digit number that appears in the bottom left corner of your check. The transit number is the five-digit number that appears next to the institution number. The account number is printed next to the transit number on the bottom of your check.

If you change your account number, your new account is opened with the same institution name, institution and transit numbers. To change your institution name, you must contact your payroll department.

Please note that the first pay period after enrolling in direct deposit, you will still receive a payroll check due to a pre-notification process. Pre-notification is where a zero deposit amount transaction is sent through the system to validate that the routing transit and bank account numbers are correct.
You may select or enter a bank name. If you select the bank, the name and the routing number will automatically be entered. You have the ability to enter a different routing number, if necessary.
Typically, if you can write checks against an account, it is a checking account. With a savings account, you do not write checks against it and, generally, use deposit or withdrawal slips only.

Sometimes the numbers on checks and deposit slips differ, so it is important that you determine your routing and account numbers by looking at one of your personal checks (rather than a deposit slip). If you are opening an account with a credit union or a savings account, we suggest you confirm the routing and account numbers with that bank.

The routing number is the nine-digit number that appears in the bottom left corner of your check. It is also referred to as an ABA number or Transit Routing number. The account number is printed next to the routing number on the bottom of your check.
If you need to change the Routing and/or Account number, close this account and add a new account with new information. To change your bank name you must contact your payroll department.

For example, you have set up two accounts: A checking account and a savings account. You have determined that your checking account will be your default account. If your net pay is $1,000, and you deposit $50 into your savings account, the amount deposited into your checking (default) account is $950.

If for reason you should receive $100 of additional pay (bonus/commissions/overtime), your net pay would be $1,100. Fifty dollars would go to your savings account and $1,050 would be deposited into your checking account because the default account takes 100% of the remaining balance.

Deposits are made into your accounts in the order in which you enter them into the system, except for your default account. Your default account is always deposited last. However, you have the ability to redefine the deposit sequence but the default account will always be deposited last.
If you want to deposit a percent of your net pay into an account, click Percent and type the number indicating the percent to be deposited. You do not need to type the percent sign.

If you want to deposit a flat amount into an account, click Amount and type the amount that should be deposited into the account. You do not need to type the amount sign. If the deposit amount is a whole number, you do not need to type the decimal point.
Because this is your default account, you cannot change the amount that is being deposited. If you want to change the amount, you must designate a new default account.

A default account ensures that all of your net pay is allocated somewhere. If you choose to deposit only a portion of your net pay, your paycheck will act like your default account. However, if you choose to deposit all of your net pay via direct deposit, you must specify a default account.

You have decided that you want $50 of your pay deposited into a holiday fund. The remainder you want to receive via normal paycheck distribution. In this situation, your paycheck becomes the default account. If for some reason you should receive additional pay (bonus/commission/overtime), that extra pay would show up in your paycheck, not your holiday fund.
The system requires that it be designated as 100%(that is, 100% of anything that is left after all other deposits have been made).

You may select the institution name. If you select an institution the name, institution, and transit numbers will automatically be entered. You have the ability to enter a different transit number, if necessary.
Because this is a default account, you cannot specify an amount. It must be designated as 100%.

Changes made on this screen may or may not be reflected on your next paycheck, depending on your payroll cutoff. That is, if you update a direct deposit account the day before payday, it is unlikely that your change will appear on your paycheck until the following payroll cycle.
You will be presented with this authorization form when you add, close or make a change to a direct deposit account.
With this authorization form you give consent to your employer to interact with
when depositing your pay and, if necessary, correcting any errors.
